text: i’m not convinced regarding giving the marketer drag and drop options … we are already kinda doing this for them anyway … but in a very controlled way, in a way that they can’t break things or move away from the original layout. Using flexible columns, repeater groups, choice fields and boolean fields

The thing is, not every HubSpot portal has access to a developer and they're experiencing a lot of pain whenever they need to make changes to their site.

It's also important to note that drag and drop will always be something you can turn on or off at the template level. So, if you don't want to add drag and drop to your templates, the marketer won't see that option.

the scenario is that they can choose to havemultiple columns of content on a per page basis, they can choose the sizing of the modules. The difference is that instead of focusing on building a template that limits the marketer, you can focus on building really good custom modules.

You can create the same layouts now, but YOU the developer have to build it, and it takes some time.  Marketers the ones driving the push for these sorts of interfaces, want to not have to bug developers for every minor change they want to make.

That’s why we give them rich text editors and fields and all that in the first place, so they don’t have to come to us.

building templates that allow marketers to control the columns like that is just an expansion of this  philosophy.
This doesn’t hurt developers in the sense of lessening the amount of work we need to do - it just shifts the work to being focusing on re-usable high quality custom modules instead.
